"**Let My Love Open the Door** " is a song written and performed by [Pete
Townshend](/wiki/Pete_Townshend "Pete Townshend") from his 1980 album _[Empty
Glass](/wiki/Empty_Glass "Empty Glass")_. It reached the top ten in the United
States in that same year, reaching number nine.[1][2] It reached number five
in Canada.[3]

##
Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Let_My_Love_Open_the_Door&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Background")]

Although Townshend is a devotee to the religious guru [Meher
Baba](/wiki/Meher_Baba "Meher Baba"), he claimed in the liner notes of his
_[Anthology](/wiki/Anthology_\(Pete_Townshend_album\) "Anthology \(Pete
Townshend album\)")_ CD that "Jesus sings" on the track.[4]

"Let My Love Open the Door" was released as the second single from _Empty
Glass_ in Britain, where it was backed with the non-album tracks "Classified"
and "Greyhound Girl." The song was a minor British hit, reaching #46.[5] The
song saw more success when it was released as the debut single from _Empty
Glass_ in America, where the song reached #9.[6] It was Pete Townshend's only
solo top 10 hit on the [_Billboard_ Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100
"Billboard Hot 100"), but [The Who](/wiki/The_Who "The Who")'s song "[I Can
See For Miles](/wiki/I_Can_See_For_Miles "I Can See For Miles")," which was
written by Townshend, reached the same position on the chart 13 years earlier.

Initially, Townshend's manager despised the track due to it "not sounding like
Townshend," and wanted it to be removed from _Empty Glass._[4] However, upon
the song's chart success, his manager called to apologize.

Despite the song's critical and commercial success, Pete Townshend did not
consider it one of his best songs. He told _[Rolling
Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ in an interview that "Let My Love
Open the Door" was "just a ditty," also claiming that he preferred his minor
US hit "[A Little Is Enough](/wiki/A_Little_Is_Enough "A Little Is Enough")"
from the same album.[4]

In 1996, Townshend released a new version of the song, called "the E. Cola
mix", turning the song into a ballad. This version appeared in different
television shows and film soundtracks.

##
Covers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Let_My_Love_Open_the_Door&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Covers")]

  * A version of this song by [Luminate](/wiki/Luminate "Luminate") appears on _The Covers EP_.[10]
  * It was also covered by [M. Ward](/wiki/M._Ward "M. Ward") (for the 2005 [Starbucks](/wiki/Starbucks "Starbucks") compilation album, _[Sweetheart 2005: Love Songs](/wiki/Sweetheart_2005:_Love_Songs "Sweetheart 2005: Love Songs")_)
  * Christian rock group [Audio Adrenaline](/wiki/Audio_Adrenaline "Audio Adrenaline") covered this song on their 1999 album _[Underdog](/wiki/Underdog_\(Audio_Adrenaline_album\) "Underdog \(Audio Adrenaline album\)")_.
  * [Natalie Imbruglia](/wiki/Natalie_Imbruglia "Natalie Imbruglia") covered the song on her album _[Male](/wiki/Male_\(Natalie_Imbruglia_album\) "Male \(Natalie Imbruglia album\)")_ released in 2015.
  * [Great Big Sea](/wiki/Great_Big_Sea "Great Big Sea") covered the song on their 2012 album _[XX](/wiki/XX_\(Great_Big_Sea_album\) "XX \(Great Big Sea album\)")_.
  * [Roger Daltrey](/wiki/Roger_Daltrey "Roger Daltrey") covered the song in 2015 for a campaign involving [Teen Cancer America](/w/index.php?title=Teen_Cancer_America&action=edit&redlink=1 "Teen Cancer America \(page does not exist\)") and [First Citizens Bank](/wiki/First_Citizens_Bank "First Citizens Bank").[11] A full version was released in February 2016, with all proceeds going to Teen Cancer America.
  * The group Rogue Wave also covered it in "Cover me" released in 2017.

## List of Films, TV Shows, and Other Media featuring the
track[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Let_My_Love_Open_the_Door&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: List of Films, TV Shows, and Other Media featuring the track")]

The song has been used frequently in film, most notably the comedy genre,
often as trailer music for movies such as _[Jerry Maguire](/wiki/Jerry_Maguire
"Jerry Maguire")_ and _[How Do You Know](/wiki/How_Do_You_Know_\(film\) "How
Do You Know \(film\)")_ , and then as [end credit](/wiki/End_credits "End
credits") song for _[Mr. Deeds](/wiki/Mr._Deeds "Mr. Deeds")_ in 2002;
_[Jersey Girl](/wiki/Jersey_Girl_\(2004_film\) "Jersey Girl \(2004 film\)")_
and _[Along Came Polly](/wiki/Along_Came_Polly "Along Came Polly")_ , both in
2004. It was featured in the following films and TV series:

  * _[Look Who's Talking](/wiki/Look_Who%27s_Talking "Look Who's Talking")_ (1989)
  * _[Grosse Pointe Blank](/wiki/Grosse_Pointe_Blank#Soundtrack "Grosse Pointe Blank")_ as "E. Cola Mix" (1997)
  * _[Mr. Deeds](/wiki/Mr._Deeds "Mr. Deeds")_ (2002)
  * _[Jersey Girl](/wiki/Jersey_Girl_\(2004_film\) "Jersey Girl \(2004 film\)")_ as "E. Cola Mix" (2004)
  * _[Along Came Polly](/wiki/Along_Came_Polly "Along Came Polly")_ (2004)
  * _[Click](/wiki/Click_\(2006_film\) "Click \(2006 film\)")_ (in trailers) (2006)
  * _[Dan in Real Life](/wiki/Dan_in_Real_Life "Dan in Real Life")_ (2007)
  * _[Doctors (soap opera)](/wiki/Doctors_\(soap_opera\) "Doctors \(soap opera\)")_ , season 11, episode 106 (2009)
  * _[Old Dogs](/wiki/Old_Dogs_\(film\) "Old Dogs \(film\)")_ (2009)
  * _[How Do You Know](/wiki/How_Do_You_Know_\(film\) "How Do You Know \(film\)")_ (in trailers) (2010)
  * _[Take Me Home Tonight](/wiki/Take_Me_Home_Tonight_\(film\) "Take Me Home Tonight \(film\)")_ as "E. Cola Mix" (2011)
  * _[_Red Dog_](/wiki/Red_Dog_\(film\) "Red Dog \(film\)") (2011)_
  * _[Hit and Run](/wiki/Hit_and_Run_\(2012_film\) "Hit and Run \(2012 film\)")_ (2012)
  * _[The Newsroom](/wiki/The_Newsroom_\(U.S._TV_series\) "The Newsroom \(U.S. TV series\)")_ (2012) - cover by [Luminate](/wiki/Luminate "Luminate") used in the second season finale, "Election Night, Part II" (September 15, 2013)
  * _[Californication](/wiki/Californication_\(TV_series\) "Californication \(TV series\)")_ , season 7, episode 1 (April 13, 2014)
  * _[The Goldbergs](/wiki/The_Goldbergs_\(2013_TV_series\) "The Goldbergs \(2013 TV series\)")_ , season 1 "Why're You Hitting Yourself?" (2013) the "E. Cola Mix" played at end before credits. Also played in Season 4, Episode 15 "So Swayze It's Crazy" (2017).
  * A cover of the song by Stacey Markus is used at the end of episode nine ("The Invitation") of the 2015 [Netflix](/wiki/Netflix "Netflix") original series _[Grace and Frankie](/wiki/Grace_and_Frankie "Grace and Frankie")_ , starring [Jane Fonda](/wiki/Jane_Fonda "Jane Fonda") and [Lily Tomlin](/wiki/Lily_Tomlin "Lily Tomlin").
  * The song is featured in a Walmart Christmas holiday television commercial which started airing in early December 2017.[12]
  * _[Lethal Weapon (TV series)](/wiki/Lethal_Weapon_\(TV_series\) "Lethal Weapon \(TV series\)")_ , season 2, episode 9 "Fools Rush In" play the song performed by "Rogue wave" (2017). [13]
